questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient is brought to the hospital with an altered state of consciousness. He has a history of chronic liver disease. On examination, there are mild ascites and tremors. Laboratory values show: Total Bilirubin - 2.5 mg/dL Albumin - 3 g/dL INR=2.0 According to the given data, the patient belongs to which class of Child Turcotte Pugh score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The total score for the given patient amounts to 2+2+2+2+3=11 points, and hence he belongs to CTP Class C. Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) Scoring System and this patient have Grade 3 encephalopathy.

choices.text: Left medial segment, left lateral segment

questions.text: The liver is divided into right and left lobes and contains 8 Couinaud segments; concerning hepatic anatomy, the falciform ligament divides which of the following two components of the liver?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Left medial segment, left lateral segment 
The falciform ligament is a Sickle-shaped ligament that divides the liver's left lobe into the left medial and left lateral segments. The liver is the largest organ after the skin. It weighs about 1500 grams. It lies under the diaphragm in the right upper abdomen and mid abdomen and extends to the left upper abdomen.

choices.text: Produced by maternal hepatocytes during Pregnancy
Conditions with elevated levels of AFP are HCC, Non-seminomatous testicular tumour, Pregnancy and Gastric cancer
Levels >400 ng/mL with arterial enhancement on CT are suggestive of HCC
Normal adult serum AFP level is <20 ng/mL

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of yellowish discolouration of skin for the past 15 days. On physical examination, he has icteric sclera. A CT scan of the abdomen reveals a hypervascular mass in the liver. You order an AFP tumour marker test. Which of the following is not a feature of the tumour marker AFP?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Produced by maternal hepatocytes during Pregnancy 
AFP is produced by fetal hepatocytes and yolk sac, not maternal hepatocytes, during Pregnancy. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) Tumor marker most commonly used for the detection and management of hepatocellular carcinoma The oncofetal protein is produced by fetal hepatocytes and yolk-sac Elevated in utero, falls to low levels after birth and again elevates during Pregnancy Conditions with elevated levels of AFP: Hepatocellular carcinoma Tumors of gonadal origin (Nonseminomatous testicular tumor) Gastric cancer Pregnancy Acute or chronic hepatitis Inflammatory bowel disease.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman was admitted to your hospital with recurrent upper abdominal pain for one year. The patient also had presented with diabetes/glucose intolerance, steatorrhea, gallstones, and achlorhydria.. Computed tomography (CT) indicated an isodense mass of 8.4 cm×3.7 cm in the body and tail of the pancreas with notable enhancement. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Somatostatinoma 
Gallstones are associated with somatostatinoma. • Somatostatinoma: Somatostatinoma syndrome is a triad of diabetes mellitus, steatorrhea, and gallstones, but it also includes weight loss and hypochlorhydria. Because somatostatin inhibits pancreatic and biliary secretions, patients with a somatostatinoma present with gallstones due to bile stasis, diabetes due to inhibition of insulin secretion, and steatorrhea due to inhibition of pancreatic exocrine secretion and bile secretion Most somatostatinomas originate in the proximal pancreas or the pancreatoduodenal groove, with the ampulla and periampullary area as the most common site (60%) The most common presentations are abdominal pain, jaundice, and cholelithiasis. Of tumours, >70% are malignant, with metastasis to the liver or lymph nodes commonly noted at the time of diagnosis. They are rarely associated with MEN1 syndrome but are associated with Von Recklinghausen disease and pheochromocytoma. Diagnosis is confirmed by elevated serum somatostatin levels. Treatment involves complete excision of the tumour and cholecystectomy if there is no metastatic disease. Somatostatinoma syndrome is a triad of diabetes mellitus, steatorrhea, and gallstones, but it also includes weight loss and hypochlorhydria.

questions.text: A young man presented with pain abdomen, diarrhoea, and fever gradually increasing in a step ladder pattern over the past 2 weeks. A Widal test confirmed the diagnosis and he was admitted. A few days later, he developed intestinal perforation and was taken up for exploratory laparotomy. Which of the following findings would you see in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Longitudinal intestinal ulcers
Typhoid causes longitudinal ulcers.
Typhoid fever is caused by Salmonella typhi. It presents with step-ladder fever and abdominal pain after an incubation period of 10-20 days. Over the next week, the patient can develop:
- Distension
- Diarrhoea
- Splenomegaly
- Characteristic rose spots on the abdomen caused by a vasculitis
Surgical complications of typhoid are:
- Paralytic ileus
- Intestinal haemorrhage
- Free ileal perforation (characteristically occurs during the third week of the illness)
- Cholecystitis
- Longitudinal ulcers (usually situated in the distal ileum)
Diagnosis of typhoid is confirmed by culture of blood or stool.
Treatment is by antibiotics, usually chloramphenicol.

questions.text: A 50-year-old alcoholic patient presents with a history of waxing and waning jaundice for the past 2 months. His CT examination reveals, dilatation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct. What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Periampullary carcinoma
In the given scenario, a characteristic history of waxing and waning jaundice along with a dilated common bile duct and pancreatic duct on CT scan, points to a diagnosis of periampullary carcinoma. Periampullary carcinoma arises from the vicinity of the ampulla of Vater. Patients with hereditary polyposis syndromes, such as familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) have a higher risk of developing it.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of hematuria. A 2x2 cm bladder mass is seen which is a low-grade transitional cell carcinoma. Which among the following is the ideal management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Transurethral resection of the tumour
This patient with low-grade 2x2 cm bladder cancer is likely to have non-muscle invasive bladder carcinoma (NMIBC) should undergo transurethral resection of the bladder tumor (TURBT) for accurate staging purposes.
Bladder cancer is graded (G1/2/3) based on level of differentiation. NMIBC includes stages Tis (in-situ), Ta (non- invasive papillary carcinoma), and T1 (invades lamina propria) while muscle invasive bladder cancer (MIBC) Includes stages T2 (invades muscularis propria), T3 (invades perivesicular soft tissue), and T4 (invades adfjacent organs). NMIBC accounts for almost 70% of cases at presentation.

questions.text: A patient with recurrent pain in the right hypochondrium, nausea, and vomiting is diagnosed with biliary dyskinesia. Which of the following is least useful in the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

USG

USG is the least useful investigation in the diagnosis of biliary dyskinesia or sphincter of Oddi dysfunction since the findings can be normal or show non-specific changes such as dilatation of the common bile duct.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with recurrent episodes of right flank pain, hematuria, and a history of urinary tract infections. Urine analysis shows alkaline urine with a pH of 8.0. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Triple phosphate stone

The patient is having urinary tract infection is most likely underlying cause of Triple phosphate stone.

questions.text: An alcoholic male patient diagnosed with hollow viscus perforation is taken up for laparotomy. Intraoperatively, a 2 cm-sized perforation is seen in the gastric region as shown below. How can this patient be managed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Omental pedicle repair
The given scenario of an alcoholic male patient of gastric perforation showing intra-op large 2 cm size perforation can be managed by an Omental pedicle repair.

questions.text: While performing emergency laparotomy for an unstable RTA case with blunt abdominal trauma, the surgeon notices a hematoma around the left kidney. What will be the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Single-shot intravenous pyelography
The next step in the surgical management of the patient found to have a hematorna around the kidney, intraoperatively, will be a single-shot intravenous pyelography (IVP).

questions.text: A patient is shifted for emergency laparotomy for the management of an intra-abdominal haemorrhage, following a road traffic accident. Intraoperatively, you find an active bleed from the liver. Which of the following techniques will you use to control the bleed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Clamping the hepatoduodenal ligament
The hepatoduodenal ligament can be clamped to decrease active hemorrhage from the liver. This is called Pringle’s maneuver.
This maneuver applies pressure on the portal triad which contains bile duct, portal vein and hepatic artery. This helps distinguish hepatic arterial and portal venous bleeding from hepatic vein bleeding. Hepatic venous bleed will persist with the hepatoduodenal ligament clamped. The liver laceration can then be explored and any actively bleeding vessels controlled with suture ligation.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the right upper quadrant on the second postoperative day following a cholecystectomy. Evaluation reveals a collection in the subhepatic space. A bile leak was suspected. Which of the following is the best investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

ERCP

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the best investigation in a patient suspected of post- cholecystectomy biliary leaks.
Patients with post-cholecystectomy biliary leak usually present with fever, jaundice and abdominal pain. USG is used for an initial evaluation in such cases and can show a collection in the sub-hepatic space.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man was referred to the surgery OPD from the infertility clinic. On inspection, the scrotum appeared as in the image. On palpation, a bag of worms sensation was felt. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Palomo procedure
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a varicocele. As this patient is young and infertile, varicocelectomy is indicated and a Palomo procedure may be performed.
Varicocele may present with a dull aching scrotal pain and enlargement. Additionally, patients may have infertility. A bag of worms, which gets prominent on Valsalva’s maneuver is palpated due to the engorged pampiniform plexus.

questions.text: A patient with gastric adenocarcinoma is posted for surgery. What is the extent of negative margin you should remove around the tumor for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

5 cm
In surgical resection of gastric cancer, at least 5cm of negative margin should be removed around the tumor.

choices.text: Careful observation with imaging every 6 months

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with right upper quadrant pain for the last 6 weeks. On examination, a firm mass is palpable in the right hypochondrium region. CECT abdomen shows a 6 cm cystic structure in the right lobe of the liver along with water lily sign. Which of the following is the ideal management for him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Albendazole therapy + PAIR
The given imaging finding on CECT is suggestive of class CE3A hydatid cyst disease of the liver.
The ideal management for type CE3A hydatid cyst of dimension >5cm is Albendazole therapy 400 mg twice daily and PAIR (puncture, aspiration, injection, and reaspiration) therapy.

questions.text: A patient with acute pancreatitis underwent a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen. CT scan shows diffuse enlargement of the pancreas without necrosis. What will be the CT severity index of the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

1
The CT severity index (CTSI) of this patient will be 1. The CT severity index for grading of acute pancreatitis is determined as the sum of two scores:
Balthazar score: grading of pancreatitis
Necrosis score: grading of the extent of pancreatic necrosis
The Balthazar score for diffuse enlargement of the pancreas is 1. Since there is no necrosis, the necrosis score of the patient is zero. Hence the CTS index of this patient is 1.

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis. Specimen revealed that she had gall bladder carcinoma infiltrating the muscularis layer. What is the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Extended cholecystectomy 
In the given clinical scenario, gallbladder carcinoma with T1b lesions, wherein the tumor penetrates the muscle layer.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented with fever, chills, and dysuria. On per-rectal examination, his prostate was tender and boggy. His PSA level was 7.4 ng/dl. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Antibiotic therapy
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute bacterial prostatitis and should be managed by antibiotics. A rigorous and prolonged treatment for 2-6 weeks with an antibiotic that penetrates the prostate wall is indicated (trimethoprim, ciprofloxacin or aminoglycoside). Incomplete infection eradication lead to recurrent attacks and chronic prostatitis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with dysphagia and postprandial chest pain that is relieved by loud belching. On examination, the patient had pallor. Chest radiography showed an intrathoracic gas bubble. What is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

CT scan with oral contrast 
The given clinical scenario with X-ray findings showing a retrocardiac gas bubble are consistent with the diagnosis of a hiatus hernia. A CT scan with oral contrast is the best method of diagnosis. It highlights the gastric anatomy but also helps to identify other structures involved in the hiatal hernia. Hiatus hernia is the protrusion of any abdominal structure other than the esophagus into the thoracic cavity through a widening of the hiatus of the diaphragm.
